conclusion: To determine the time during which there is an induced current in the square conductor frame, we need to analyze the motion of the frame relative to the magnetic field and the conditions under which an induced emf is generated.

A magnetic field B exists only within a certain region of space (the 'magnetic field'). An induced emf is generated when a conducting loop (or part of it) moves through a magnetic field. For an emf to be induced, the magnetic flux through the loop must change as the loop moves.
The frame is moving horizontally with velocity v. The width of the magnetic field is d, and the side length of the frame is l.

premise: The frame enters the magnetic field when the left edge of the frame crosses into the field. The frame exits the magnetic field when the right edge of the frame crosses out of the field.
conclusion: We need to calculate the times at which these events occur.

premise: The left edge of the frame starts entering the field at time t = 0 (assuming the frame starts at x = 0).
conclusion: The left edge enters completely into the field when the left edge has moved l/2 distance into the field: t1 = l/(2v).

premise: The right edge starts exiting the field at time t1.
conclusion: The right edge fully exits the field when the right edge has moved another l/2 distance out of the field after entering: t2 = (d + l/2)/v.

premise: The total time T during which there is an induced current is the difference between the exit and entry times: T = t2 - t1.

conclusion: The time during which there is an induced current in the frame is d/v.
